title: Auditing Elon Musk's Impact on Hate Speech and Bots

last_post.content:
New paper on auditing Elon's early impact on Twitter.
- Hateful users became more hateful
- Hate increased dramatically
- There was no overall change in bots

Paper (accepted to ICWSM 2023) is here:
https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04129

Following Elsevier's decision to raise the article processing charge for NeuroImage to $3,450, all editors (inc. chief editors) from NeuroImage and NeuroImage:Reports have resigned, effective immediately.

I am joining this action and have also resigned.

Full announcement: https://imaging-neuroscience.org/Announcement.pdf

Big news: Entire editorial board at NeuroImage resigns to start a new journal (same scope) at MIT Press:

https://imaging-neuroscience.org

Big news for the #mri #fmri #eeg #meg @fmri communities

title: The EU's Proposed CRA Law May Have Unintended Consequences for the Python Ecosystem

last_post.content: Another warning from #OpenSource foundations that the EU Cyber Resilience Act and Product Liability Act could have profound consequences on #FOSS communities - more folks should be more aware of this conversation. https://pyfound.blogspot.com/2023/04/the-eus-proposed-cra-law-may-have.html

NPR should get off Twitter. The New York Times should get off Twitter. The Washington Post, CBS, CNN, The Los Angeles Times should get off Twitter. Every journalist should get off Twitter.

You’re putting your product in the hands of a petty tyrant. I’m losing faith in your judgment.

Why is this hard?

https://www.npr.org/2023/04/05/1168158549/twitter-npr-state-affiliated-media

Hello Fediverse! 👋

#Wikipedia :wikipedia: is a multilingual free online encyclopedia written and maintained by a community of volunteers, known as Wikipedians, through open collaboration and using a wiki-based editing system called MediaWiki. -- or so says our Wikipedia article (https://w.wiki/W).

Follow for cool facts, behind-the-scenes details on editing processes and tips on getting started contributing!

#Introduction #FreeCulture #FreeContent #OpenKnowledge #wiki #CreativeCommons
article on weaving chatGPT into library cataloguing workflow https://thisismattmiller.com/post/using-gpt-on-library-collections/ if it wasn't already obvious, this is coming soon

title: The End of Computer Magazines in America

last_post.content:
The last two computer magazines die.
Here's my second book of the year, about the death of the magazine.
https://www.technologizer.com/2023/04/15/the-end-of-computer-magazines-in-america/
+
https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/magazine-9781501394966/

At @knightcolumbia I'm co-organizing what I think is the first symposium on the topic of algorithmic amplification on social media — April 28/29 (NYC and online). I'm told we have over 600 registrations already. We'll be moving to a waitlist for in-person participation soon. Register to hear from ~30 leading thinkers on the topic: https://knightcolumbia.org/events/optimizing-for-what-algorithmic-amplification-and-society

Wikipedia is now on Mastodon, at @wikipedia!

They've taken an interesting approach here, as it is an account run by the community, where everyone can contribute (explanation here: https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/@Wikipedia). At the same time, it is verified on the official homepage of wikipedia.org, as you can see in the screenshot.

Personally, I think this suits the spirit of the fediverse that the Wikipedia account is not a PR department, but community members building something together!

If you’re a fan of literary #indiegames and have never heard of “The Gostak,” one of the wildest experiments to come out of the 90s/00s era #InteractiveFiction renaissance, you’ll want to read this article. There’s never been another game like it before or since. https://if50.substack.com/p/the-gostak #gamestudies #50YearsOfTextGames

title: I declined to share my medical data with advertisers at my doctor’s office. One company claimed otherwise

last_post.content: The problem with "opting out" of data tracking is that your requests can be ignored. Alex Rosenblat traced what happened to her medical opt-out requests when she was pregnant. What she found was that privilege vigilance isn't enough. https://www.statnews.com/2023/04/07/medical-data-privacy-phreesia/

The R-Ladies Global Team is recruiting! 🤗

We have openings for ✨22✨ new volunteers. 😲

Your support would relieve current volunteers from serving in multiple roles as well as allow us to create new teams and expand existing teams, all of which is critical to sustainable growth and maintenance of the organization. 💜

👀 Details:
https://www.rladies.org/news/2023-04-11-global-team-recruiting/

title: Prompt injection: what’s the worst that can happen?

last_post.content:
I had forgotten about this but it looks like my message-in-a-bottle got picked up by the web crawlers.

Also shows how it's not too difficult to add data into a search index that gets blended into an LLM's output. More in Simon's post here: https://simonwillison.net/2023/Apr/14/worst-that-can-happen/

title: Now, you can embed Mastodon posts in Medium stories

last_post.content:
We added #Mastodon to Embedly. So now Mastodon links embed more naturally on #Medium and every other service that uses Embedly to handle embeds.
https://blog.medium.com/now-you-can-embed-mastodon-posts-in-medium-stories-99b11d0baa7f

"Software Design by Example: A Tool-Based Introduction with JavaScript" (https://third-bit.com/sdxjs/), "Research Software Engineering with Python" (https://merely-useful.tech/py-rse/), and "JavaScript for Data Science" (https://third-bit.com/js4ds/) are all free to read online - the Python version of "Software Design by Example" should join them in a few months.

Been learning a lot from discussions surrounding our 'Beyond Single-Mindedness' paper https://doi.org/10.1111/cogs.13230

One lesson is that the radical-yet-inclusive stance we take can be disorienting. Yes, we believe that putting interaction at the heart of cognition is a valuable and productive move. No, that doesn't mean we think single-minded work is useless. The neat thing about a figure-ground reversal is that it affords multiple ways of looking: https://markdingemanse.net/beyond/figure-ground/

title: Twitter Suspends User For Sharing Washington Post Story About Pentagon Docs Leaker

last_post.content:
Twitter suspended my account again.

Here’s what I wrote in the appeal. Yes I included @mmasnick‘s link.

<< Why have you resuspended this account again? What rule did it break? You suspended it for trying to share a WaPo link. Then you unsuspended this account and marked tweet screenshot “sensitive media.” Now you’ve again suspended the account for no reason. https://www.techdirt.com/2023/04/14/twitter-suspends-user-for-sharing-washington-post-story-about-pentagon-docs-leaker/ >>

Twitter unsuspended the backup account. And apparently suspended and then unsuspended my prof account.

title: In re: Facebook, Inc. Consumer Privacy User Profile Litigation

last_post.content:
Do you reside in the USA? Were you a Facebook user between 2007-22?

Then Meta owes you money!

That's right, because Facebook has accessed user data without permission, various class action lawsuits have resulted in them having to pay a total of $725 million to its users.

And who are they paying? Almost every American who's used Facebook!

Want that money? Here's where to file that claim:

https://www.facebookuserprivacysettlement.com/

First #RaspberryPi earned a shitstorm by hiring an ex-cop specialized in hidden surveillance.

- https://pine64.com/
- https://beagleboard.org/
- http://www.orangepi.org/
- https://www.banana-pi.org/
- https://www.hardkernel.com/
- https://www.friendlyelec.com/
- https://www.olimex.com/

current status: googling "death of the sun" to explain how much bigger 64-bit integers are than 32-bit integers

(2^32 seconds is ~136 years, 2^64 seconds is ~500 billion years https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Year_2038_problem)

Must admin that @pandas_dev 2.0 slipped right past me: https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/dev/whatsnew/v2.0.0.html

Favourite pure quality of life change - https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/dev/whatsnew/v2.0.0.html#value-counts-sets-the-resulting-name-to-count

title: Two Hearts As One - A Colorful Portrait Art Print by Mark Tisdale

last_post.content:
A month ago I shared a #colorful #romantic scene with a man and a woman and a commenter here said they'd like to see something similar with two men instead. This is a result of that challenge. ❤️

Find it here: https://mark-tisdale.pixels.com/featured/two-hearts-as-one-a-colorful-portrait-mark-tisdale.html?product=art-print

Sharing is always welcome whether through boosts or otherwise. This is how I pay the bills. ⭐

#MastoArt #GayArt #Gay #LGBTQ #LGBT #LGBTQIA #DigitalArt #Painting #MarkOnArt

The most interesting critique of #PeerReview I've read in a long time is by @a_m_mastroianni.
https://www.experimental-history.com/p/science-is-a-strong-link-problem

The gist: We treat science as a weak-link problem (in which we fear opening the gates to the worst stuff) when when it's properly a strong-link problem (in which we should fear closing the gates to the best stuff).

h/t @DailyNous, who applied Mastroianni's thesis to #philosophy.
https://dailynous.com/2023/04/17/whats-so-bad-about-bad-philosophy/

#Academia, #AcademicMastodon
@academicchatter

NPR and CBC have suspended the use of their Twitter accounts. Finally.

Everyone can email ask@cbc.ca

Go here to msg NPR managment :

https://help.npr.org/contact/s/contact?request=Contact-NPR-management

#CBC #NPR

Hillfolk, the game of dramatic interaction, is one day away from leaving the Bundle of Holding. Catch this wildly great PDF deal before it storms out dramatically.

I just released #Bubblemania, my first #GenerativeArt project on #FXHash in over 9 months and a little gift to some in the growing #GenerativeArt community here on Mastodon and to other randomly chosen collectors of my previous pieces.

https://www.fxhash.xyz/generative/26702

This small project is several things:

1. First and foremost, it's a little, light "visual ASMR" treat to bring some positivity into your day - some "Maluma" softness to contrast the more common "Takete" of contemporary generative art aesthetics[1].

2. A small gift to celebrate the fledgling generative art/design community on Mastodon: 20 of the 128 tokens are given to some of the people in that slowly growing community, with the remainder given as Thank You (and smoke signal/sign of life) to some of my existing collectors, randomly chosen via lottery script[2].

3. For those so inclined, and with a bit of hand-holding, ChatGPT explains the _true_ conceptual depths of this project much better than I ever could:

"The bubbles in this generative art piece serve as a reflection of the human experience, reminding us of our own impermanence and the ephemeral nature of all things. The piece invites us to contemplate the fundamental questions of human existence and speaks to our innate curiosity and desire to understand the world around us.

Through the convergence of science and art, this piece reveals the infinite complexity and unpredictability of the world while also hinting at the underlying order that exists within the chaos of the universe. It reminds us that even in the midst of uncertainty, there is beauty and order to be found, and that it is through the pursuit of knowledge and understanding that we can find meaning and purpose in our lives."

Isn't that lovely & who can argue with that?! :)

4. I often revisit projects/ideas after many years, mainly to re-examine them with new eyes/knowledge/tools and/or to get answers/verification which I couldn't get earlier. This is one of these instances. So for the more rational-minded, this is a TypeScript/GLSL (WebGL) version of an older Clojure/Houdini project (from 2016) to generate a Voronoi via the simulation of intersecting sphere meshes (aka foam bubbles). In this new version the sim & deformations are done in realtime (~4M vertices, mainly via vertex shader). Also added some _basic_ physics and procedural textures to create more of a quirky character (hopefully complemented by the different color themes and other params).

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bouba/kiki_effect
[2] https://gist.github.com/postspectacular/3d970e02570b7dfd32d03d43e1e7e3e0

title: The Secret Water Footprint of AI Technology – The Markup

last_post.content: "training GPT‑3 in Microsoft’s state-of-the-art U.S. data centers can directly consume 700,000 liters of clean freshwater (enough to produce 370 BMW cars or 320 Tesla electric vehicles), and the water consumption would have been tripled if training were done in Microsoft’s data centers in Asia" https://themarkup.org/hello-world/2023/04/15/the-secret-water-footprint-of-ai-technology

title: Advertisers See Elon Musk As A Liability As They Avoid Twitter

last_post.content:
"Advertisers See Elon Musk As A Liability As They Avoid Twitter"

https://www.techdirt.com/2023/04/17/advertisers-see-elon-musk-as-a-liability-as-they-avoid-twitter/ #birdsite #musk @mmasnick

"Advertisers are now speaking about it and they have a simple message: The problem is Elon Musk. Twitter was basically just fine as an ad platform. Not great, could be better, but it was okay. But the real issue now is just that anyone with any sense at all is freaked out about how Elon Musk himself is going to destroy their brand value."

Okay, #60Minutes is saying that Google's Bard model "spoke in a foreign language it was never trained to know." I looked into what this can mean, and it appears to be a lie. Here's the evidence, curious what others found. 🧵

1-The exact language referred to seems to be Bengali.
https://dailymail.co.uk/news/article-11980033/Google-CEO-says-doesnt-fully-understand-new-AI-program-Bard-works.html
I can't stomach the 60 minutes piece; here's the Daily Mail naming it. (Will check transcript when avail.)
a list of programming playgrounds https://jvns.ca/blog/2023/04/17/a-list-of-programming-playgrounds/

I'm starting a new role next week, almost the union of my past two roles, and have been thinking about the piece I wrote when deciding to leave Stripe a lot: https://lethain.com/forty-year-career/

While I disagree with most stuff I've written 3+ years ago, this one still holds true for me.

If you installed a Linux system with disk encryption more than a couple of years ago, there's a decent chance it's using a weak key derivation function and someone who cares enough would be in a position to brute-force it. https://mjg59.dreamwidth.org/66429.html has more details and instructions on how to update to a better KDF.

title: Google CEO peddles #AIhype on CBS 60 minutes - Emily M. Bender - Medium

last_post.content:
Quick reaction thread to Sundar Pichai's appalling 60 minutes interview over the weekend.

"More generally, any time a AI booster makes this move (“we don’t understand humans either”) they’re either trying to evade accountability or trying to sell their system as some mysterious, magical, autonomous being. Reporters should recognize this and PUSH BACK."

title: File:Cornelis Norbertus Gijsbrechts - An Open Cupboard Door - 1665.jpg - Wikimedia Commons

last_post.content:
So much paper in this 1665 painting from Cornelis N. Gijsbrechts. You see an open cupboard door, as art history labelled the image, but what you also see: prints, letters, a broadside, an almanac, stored unused paper sheets. Early Modern Europe was a paper age. Gijsbrechts' painting has it all: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Cornelis_Norbertus_Gijsbrechts_-_An_Open_Cupboard_Door_-_1665.jpg
Let's focus on this in more detail, dear #paperhistory, and #bookhistory experts, and #histodons interested in the material worlds of the past. Here we go, next paper thread.

Was mir allerdings fehlt sind die Forschungsbereiche #artificialintelligence, #computerscience #digitaleconomy wo #AT dringend benötige Schlüsselkräfte verliert, statt sie zu gewinnen, wo Kapazitäten in der Grundlagenforschung und Ausbildung dringend ausgebaut werden müssten um den internationalen Anschluss nicht zu verlieren. 1. Without committing to any firm position, this is why “they’re just word prediction machines” is such a weak criticism of LLMs. There are things you can say about them that are both meaner and less reductive, so why turn to that one? But hey, I’m just a next-action machine, I guess.

i spent so much time on my #pycon2023 talk & now that it's on youtube, i noticed i forgot to remove the slide template items that say "add content here" 🙈 😆 with that said if you want to learn more about @pyOpenSci and #python packaging check it out - it's about 15 mins. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qxy7bxW72iA&t=5s

TL;DR of the research:

1. When do people want to show their disability in avatars?
a) When they feel safe
b) When platforms can show their identities

2. How do people want to show their disability in avatars?
a) Showing accessible technologies.
b) Showing the full body of the avatar.
c) Customizing text on avatars.

3. Why do people want to show their disability in avatars?
a) To show pride in their identity.
b) To convey fluctuating abilities.

Full report: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.01880.pdf

The most interesting critique of #PeerReview I've read in a long time is by @a_m_mastroianni.
https://www.experimental-history.com/p/science-is-a-strong-link-problem

The gist: We treat science as a weak-link problem (in which we fear opening the gates to the worst stuff) when when it's properly a strong-link problem (in which we should fear closing the gates to the best stuff).

h/t @DailyNous, who applied Mastroianni's thesis to #philosophy.
https://dailynous.com/2023/04/17/whats-so-bad-about-bad-philosophy/
